newsitem.title: USA: INSIGHT - T-bond futures rebound after jobs report.
newsitem.headline: INSIGHT - T-bond futures rebound after jobs report.

text.p: U.S. Treasury bond futures displayed a bullish tenacity Friday, bouncing back from early losses to take out key resistance and register a 3 1/2-month high, technicians said.
September bond futures continued to push to fresh highs in the final hour of the session and were last trading up 1 1/32 at 111-01, their highest point since reaching 111-24 on Feb. 26.
Persistent technically based buying fed the rally following this morning's mixed news on U.S. employment growth, bond traders said.

The Labor Department this morning said the U.S. economy added 138,000 jobs in May, far below expectations. However, the unemployment rate slipped to a 23-1/2 year low of 4.8 percent, and April payrolls were revised up to 323,000 from 142,000, with March jobs also revised upward.

The rally in bond futures did not catch fire until midmorning when September moved decisively above downtrend resistance near 110-03 drawn from the December highs, floor traders said. The contract had stalled repeatedly at that juncture throughout the week.
The surge touched off buy-stops clustered near 110-04 and 110-09 in the September contract, traders said. "There were boatloads of stops in there," said one floor broker.

Technical analysts said the breakout, which pushed September up through an array of moving averages after expanding the previous day's range in both directions, portended an extension to the 112-00 area.
However, some also expressed concern about excess exuberance as momentum indicators ratcheted higher.

"I'm a little concerned that the market is overbought on a short-term basis," said Michael Krauss, chief technical strategist for Chase Securities Inc. "The market is actually a lot better off than I would have thought given the news."
Krauss pointed to a daily sentiment index indicating the market had flipped to 72 percent bullish before today's session from just 27 percent last week as a cautionary signal.
Still, longterm and intermediate stochastics corroborate the market's underlying strength, said James Grauer, president of Omnitrage.
Further supporting the uptrend are daily stochastics that earlier this week turned down but could not gain momentum and truncated a cycle pattern, he said.
"When the market is in a state of equivocation, technicals take over, and the technicals are unequivocally bullish," Grauer said.
